channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Letter From India: Fixing India’s Deadly Roads
item.description: Not even politicians are safe while driving on Indian roads. To project a modern, respectable image, the country should fix that.
item.dc:creator: By MANU JOSEPH
item.media:description: Prime Minister Narendra Modi, left, placed a wreath on the coffin of India's minister of rural development, Gopinath Munde, who died in a car accident.

item.title: After Capture of Mosul, Militants Extend Control in Iraq
item.description: Sunni militants have advanced 110 miles south toward Baghdad and occupied the key oil refining town of Baiji, security officials said on Wednesday.
item.category: Islamic State of Iraq and Syria
item.dc:creator: By SUADAD AL-SALHY, ALAN COWELL and RICK GLADSTONE
item.media:description: Burned vehicles belonging to Iraqi security forces on Wednesday, the day after Sunni insurgents seized control of the city of Mosul.

item.title: Tax Breaks for Companies Like Apple and Starbucks Investigated by E.U.
item.description: Brussels officials are taking a tougher stance against deals by European Union members to let companies like Apple and Starbucks lower their taxes.
item.dc:creator: By JAMES KANTER
item.media:description: The office of Apple Operations International, a subsidiary of Apple, in Hollyhill, Cork, Ireland.

item.title: Open Source: Activists Who Challenged Egypt’s Protest Ban Are Sentenced to 15 Years
item.description: One of Egypt’s most prominent dissidents, the blogger Alaa Abdel Fattah, was arrested on Wednesday outside the Cairo court where he was convicted in absentia.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY
item.media:description: Alaa Abd El Fattah, an Egyptian activist, was forced to wait outside a courtroom at Cairo's Torah Prison on Wednesday while he was tried in absentia inside.

item.title: Bits Blog: Traffic Snarls in Europe as Taxi Drivers Protest Against Uber
item.description: The start-up that digitally links passengers and freelance drivers has expanded beyond the United States to cities including London, Paris and Berlin — all of them the sites of Wednesday’s protests.
item.dc:creator: By MARK SCOTT

item.title: Icon of Egypt's 2011 Revolt Sentenced to 15 Years
item.description: An Egyptian court on Wednesday convicted a prominent activist from the country's 2011 uprising of organizing an unauthorized protest and assaulting a policeman, sentencing him to 15 years in prison, in the latest blow to the liberal pro-democracy movement at a time of rapidly eroding freedoms.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Le Pen’s Far-Right Party Eyes Major Status in France, but Voters Are Still Deciding
item.description: Many voters in Bohain-en-Vermandois, a struggling community in the north of France, backed the far-right party in European Parliament elections, but few are ready to herald a switch.
item.dc:creator: By SUZANNE DALEY
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.media:description: “The new voters, I think we really have them now,” said Armand Pollet, the representative of the far-right National Front in the northern French town of Bohain-en-Vermandois.

item.title: Open Source: Glimpses of Mosul in Islamist Hands on YouTube
item.description: Video uploaded to YouTube appeared to offer images of Iraq’s second-largest city, Mosul, under the control of Islamist militants.
item.category: Islamic State of Iraq and Syria
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: J. K. Rowling Donates £1 Million to Oppose Scottish Breakaway
item.description: The author of the Harry Potter series gave backers of the effort to keep Scotland in the United Kingdom some high-profile financial support.
item.dc:creator: By STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: Spanish Lawmakers Clear Way for King’s Abdication
item.description: The parliamentary debate highlighted the political and territorial tensions that await Crown Prince Felipe as Catalan lawmakers abstained from the vote.
item.category: Juan Carlos I, King of Spain
item.dc:creator: By RAPHAEL MINDER

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Groggy Mornings Ahead for China’s World Cup Fans
item.description: Chinese soccer fans are expected to tune in to live World Cup matches despite games that will start at 4 in the morning.
item.category: Yingli Green Energy Holding Company Ltd
Yingli Green Energy Holding Company Ltd|YGE|NYSE
item.dc:creator: By BREE FENG
item.media:description: A soccer goalpost in a playing field at Luwan Sports Center in Shanghai.

item.title: Japan Protests Chinese Flybys Over East China Sea
item.description: In two separate incidents Wednesday, the Japanese Ministry of Defense said that Chinese Su-27 fighters flew dangerously close to Japanese planes.
item.dc:creator: By MARTIN FACKLER

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: How to Explain Americans
item.description: Italian autoworkers in Melfi were confronted by a puzzling question: How does the American mind work?
item.dc:creator: By BEPPE SEVERGNINI

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Report Links Wen Family to Cambridge Professorship
item.description: The daughter of the former Chinese prime minister Wen Jiabao is behind a charity that endowed a university post in Chinese development studies, according to a report in the British newspaper The Daily Telegraph.
item.category: London School of Economics and Political Science
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: The campus of the University of Cambridge in Cambridge, England. In January 2012, a little-known charity called the Chong Hua Foundation donated 3.7 million pounds to establish a professorship at the university in Chinese development studies.

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Reassuring Eastern Europe
item.description: Russia’s violation of accords on Ukraine means NATO can and should establish new bases in the East.
item.dc:creator: By JAMES P. RUBIN

item.title: Philippine Terror Suspect Captured Near Airport
item.description: Security forces held a top commander of the Abu Sayyaf extremist group who is on a United States list of most-wanted terrorists .
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Ecuador Breaks Its Amazon Deal
item.description: The decision to go back on a pledge to refrain from oil drilling threatens one of the world’s most biodiverse areas.
item.dc:creator: By KEVIN M. KOENIG

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: All Justice Is Local
item.description: Small communities in Rwanda and Uganda are revolutionizing postconflict justice.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By PHIL CLARK

item.title: China Rounds Up Hundreds in Crackdown on Fringe Sects
item.description: The campaign was prompted by the murder of a woman at a McDonald’s that horrified the nation and was attributed to adherents of a fringe religious group.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW JACOBS

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Beijing’s ‘White Paper’ Sets Off a Firestorm in Hong Kong
item.description: As China asserts its authority over Hong Kong, local democracy groups cry foul and warn of protests if universal suffrage is not allowed.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN WONG
item.media:description: Demonstrators displayed Hong Kong's Basic Law as toilet paper on Wednesday, while promoting a June 22 referendum on proposals for choosing the territory's next leader.

item.title: Hagel Defends Bergdahl Trade Before House Panel
item.description: Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel is the first high-level administration official to publicly face lawmakers about a prisoner swap that has angered many in both parties.
item.dc:creator: By HELENE COOPER
item.media:description: Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel testified before the House Armed Services Committee on Wednesday.

item.title: Letter From the Middle East: Appreciating the Flavors of West Bank
item.description: At a recent dinner at the United States consulate in Jerusalem, a Swiss-born chef was given a challenge of making a menu derived from West Bank food purveyors.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN

item.title: India Ink: In American Journalist’s Photographs, Rare Glimpse of India’s First Prime Minister
item.description: Photographs taken by an American journalist in 1952 offer a rare glimpse of then-prime minister Jawaharlal Nehru and his daughter Indira Gandhi on vacation in Kashmir.
item.dc:creator: By VISHNU VARMA
item.media:description: Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru, then prime minister, addressing a rally.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Beijing Police Detain Student Over Tiananmen Tweet
item.description: The student was arrested after she posted a Twitter message suggesting that a method for sending spam text messages might also be used to rally public awareness of the Tiananmen anniversary.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Despite Critics, China Asserts Democratic Progress in Hong Kong
item.description: As tensions mount in Hong Kong, the Chinese government lays out its argument for how Hong Kong has gotten better under its rule.
item.dc:creator: By GERRY MULLANY
item.media:description: The "white paper" was issued as some pro-democracy leaders in Hong Kong are threatening widespread protests if Beijing does not go far enough in allowing political changes.
